Name: BARBAN
Description: Barban is a carbamate ester that is 4-chlorobut-2-yn-1-yl ester of N-(3-chlorophenyl)carbamic acid. A herbicide, it is no longer approved for use within the European Community. It has a role as a herbicide. It is a carbamate ester, an acetylenic compound and a member of monochlorobenzenes.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Yalkowsky SH, He Y, eds; Handbook of aqueous solubility data. Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press p. 724 (2003) (2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 5-5 (1990) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 160 was calculated for barban(SRC), using water solubility of 11 mg/L,(1) and a regression-derived equation(2).  According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high (SRC), provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRP).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Kaufman DD; J Agr Food Chem 15: 582-91 (1967) (2) Still GG, Herrett RA; Herbicides: Chemistry, Degradation, and Mode of Action. 2nd Ed, Vol. 2. Kearney PC, DD Kaufman, Eds. NY,NY: Marcel Dekker, Inc (1976) (3) Bergon M et al; Agric Biol Chem 51: 1915-20 (1987)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Barban was found to disappear more rapidly in non-autoclaved soil than in autoclaved soil(1). Barban was degraded to 3-chloroaniline by a soil isolate of Penicillium sp. The barban-hydrolyzing enzyme was presumed to be an amidase(2). It was determined that the alkaline hydrolysis of barban leads to the degradation product 3-chloroaniline(3).
ANAEROBIC: Barban appeared to be stable in the presence of anaerobic microorganisms(1).

logP.References: US EPA; Estimation Programs Interface (EPI). ver. 3.11. U.S. EPA version for Windows. Washington, DC: U.S. EPA (2003). Available from, as of Mar 7, 2005: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm

mechanism_of_action.References: White-Stevens, R. (ed.). Pesticides in the Environment: Volume 3. New York: Marcel Dekker, Inc., 1977., p. 105
mechanism_of_action.Value: ... Interfering with cell division ... is believed to be the primary mode of action.

mechanism_of_action.References: Gosselin, R.E., R.P. Smith, H.C. Hodge. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 5th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1984., p. II-326

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Yalkowsky SH, He Y, eds; Handbook of aqueous solubility data. Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press p. 724 (2003) (2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 4-9 (1990) (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983) (4) Alexandrova LG, Klisenko MA; J Chromatogr 247: 255-62 (1982) (5) Amdur MO et al, eds; Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. 4th ed. NY, NY: Pergamon Press, (1991)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of barban is estimated as 1,200(SRC), derived from its water solubility of 11 mg/L(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this estimated Koc value suggests that barban is expected to have slight mobility in soil. Using TLC and aluminum oxide sorbent, the Rf value of barban was determined to be 0.5(4). The phenylcarbamate herbicides are much more water soluble than the substituted anilines(5). In spite of this, however, they are very immobile in soil systems. These compounds have been shown to be activated by adsorption to soil organic matter. Compounds in this group include barban. The mechanism of adsorption to soil organic matter is thought to involve hydrogen bonding between the carboxyl groups of the organic matter and the nitrogen and carbonyl oxygen of the carbamate(5).
